newsitem.title: KAZAKHSTAN: Kazakh grain sowing proceeds, rains expected in May.
newsitem.headline: Kazakh grain sowing proceeds, rains expected in May.

text.p: A Kazakh agriculture official said on Wednesday that dry weather would not hamper this year's grain crop and that rains were expected in May during sowing.

"We have seen higher than normal temperature levels this spring, causing problems with weeds," Nazarbek Kozhamsayitov, a weather analyst at the Agriculture Ministry, said. "But we expect rains in May."

He said sowing of spring grains in the southern regions was already underway and that sowing in the republic's northern grain belt would start in early May. Sowing in the icy north traditionally starts later.
"The western and southern parts of the country will have good weather; we're not expecting the dry weather that hit us last year," Kozhamsayitov said.
Dry weather was partly to blame for Kazakhstan's poor 1996 grain harvest, a meagre 11.6 million tonnes cleaned weight.
The government, which has said 19.4 million hectares will be sown to grains this year, is aiming for 14.0 million tonnes of output this year.
The former Soviet republic's agriculture sector has been left far behind in market reforms, with many farms privatised on paper but still operating as Soviet-style collectives.
Kazakhstan traditionally exports large amounts of grain to Russia.
